blocks.entry: lupus, i, m. kindred with λύκος; Sanscr. vrika, and our wolf, a wolf.

I.  Lit.: torva leaena lupum sequitur, lupus ipse capellam, Verg. E. 2, 63; Plin. 10, 63, 88, § 173; 8, 22, 34, § 80: Martialis lupus, sacred to Mars, Hor. C. 1, 17, 9; so, Martius, Verg. A. 9, 566: lupus femina for lupa, a she-wolf, Enn. ap. Serv. Verg. A. 2, 355 (Ann. v. 70 Vahl.); id. ap. Non. 378, 18 (ib. v. 73): lupus masculinum (est), quamquam Varro ... lupum feminam dicit, Ennium Pictoremque Fabium secutus, Quint. 1, 6, 12.—According to the belief of the Romans, if a wolf saw a man before the latter saw him, the man became dumb: vox quoque Moerim Jam fugit ipsa; lupi Moerim videre priores, Verg. E. 9, 53; cf. Plin. 8, 22, 34, § 80.—Prov.: lupus in fabulā or sermone, said of the appearance of a person when he is spoken of; as we say in English, talk of the devil, and he appears: atque eccum tibi lupum in sermone, Plaut. Stich. 4, 1, 71 (575); Ter. Ad. 537; Serv. Verg. E. 9, 54: de Varrone loquebamur: lupus in fabulā: venit enim ad me, Cic. Att. 13, 33, 4.—
senses: talk of the devil, and he appears

blocks.entry: β.  Lupum auribus tenere, to have a wolf by the ears, to be unable to hold and afraid to let go, i. e. to be in a situation of doubt and difficulty, Ter. Phorm. 505; Suet. Tib. 25.—
senses: to have a wolf by the ears
to be in a situation of doubt and difficulty

blocks.entry: γ.  Hac urget lupus, hac canis angit, on this side the wolf, on that the dog, i. e. to be placed between two fires, Hor. S. 2, 2, 64.—
senses: on this side the wolf, on that the dog
to be placed between two fires

blocks.entry: δ.  Lupos apud oves custodes relinquere, Plaut. Ps. 1, 28 (30): ovem lupo committere, to intrust sheep to a wolf, Ter. Eun. 832; cf. o praeclarum custodem ovium, ut aiunt, lupum! Cic. Phil. 3, 11, 27; cf.: plenum montano credis ovile lupo? Ov. A. A. 2, 363.—
senses: to intrust sheep to a wolf

blocks.entry: ε.  Lupo agnum eripere, of a difficult undertaking; as in English, to snatch the meat from a dog's mouth, Plaut. Poen. 3, 5, 31 (776).—
senses: to snatch the meat from a dog's mouth

blocks.entry: ζ.  Lupus observavit, dum dormitaret canes, of one who watches his opportunity to be unobserved, Plaut. Trin. 1, 2, 133 (171).—
η.  Ovīs ultro fugiat lupus, of a very improbable act, Verg. E. 8, 52.—
θ.  Tantum curamus frigora, quantum numerum (ovium) lupus, i. e. do not care at all, as the wolf does not care whether the number of the sheep is right or not, Verg. E. 7, 51.—
senses: as the wolf does not care whether the number of the sheep is right or not

blocks.entry: A.  A voracious fish, the wolf-fish or pike, Hor. S. 2, 2, 31; Plin. 9, 54, 79, § 169; 9, 17, 28, § 61; Col. 8, 16; Mart. 13, 89; Macr. S. 2, 12 bis.—
C.  A bit armed with points like wolves’ teeth (frena lupata): et placido duros (equus) accipit ore lupos, Ov. Tr. 4, 6, 3; Stat. Ach. 1, 281.—
senses: A bit armed with points like wolves’ teeth

blocks.entry: D.  A hook with which things were hoisted: in alios lupi superne ferrei injecti, Liv. 28, 3, 7; Isid. Orig. 23, 15.—
F.  The hop, a plant (Humulus lupulus), Plin. 21, 15, 50, § 86.
